Selected Answer: C
MyClassA: This class will compile without any issues.

MyClassB: This class will also compile without any issues.

MyClassC: This class will compile without any issues. It extends the Object class implicitly, as all classes in Java are subclasses of Object by default.

MyClassD: This class will compile without any issues as well. It contains the main method, which serves as the entry point for the Java application.
Option A is correct, since MyClassC will also compile - as it extends the Class Object the syntax valid.

Selected Answer: A
Any text after "//" on the same line is considered a comment and is ignored by the compiler.
A is not correct, because if no modifier is added to method, by default java will add 'protected' modifier. B is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
In Java, every method must be declared with an access modifier, which defines the visibility of the method. The access modifiers include public, private, protected, and package-private (default). The choice of access modifier determines where the method can be accessed from.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. will result in compile time error

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer as we cannot have a method inside another method.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about a Java method?

choices.B: It cannot be defined within another method.
choices.D: It cannot be defined as static final.
choices.A: It must be declared with an access modifier.
choices.C: It must accept a parameter and return a value.

Take Scanner for instance
java.util.Scanner s = new java.util.Scanner(System.in);

choices.C: Replace line n1 with import fruits;
choices.D: Replace line n2 with fruits.Apple apple = new Apple ();
choices.A: Replace line n1 with import fruits.Apple.getApple();
choices.E: Replace line n2 with fruits.Apple apple = new fruits.Apple ();
choices.B: Replace line n1 with import fruits.Apple;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
There is a breakline in the first "for"

The result is:
10 
20 

10 15 20

Selected Answer: A
The third element 20 is added to the ArrayList successfully without any errors. The ArrayList will dynamically resize itself behind the scenes to accommodate the additional element.

Therefore, you can add more than two numbers to an ArrayList even if its initial capacity is set to 2 or any other value.
